Warsaw Ecological Economics Center (a unit of the University of Warsaw I work with) performed analysis for a similar project at the Oder. Colleagues came to the conclusion that the projects on the water transport development are expedient only in very specific cases. Very important for water transport is the way investment costs (one-time long-term investments) correlate with operational costs (aimed at maintaining current work). If annual operating costs are more than 1% of investment costs, then the project, as a rule, becomes unprofitable. In the case of the Oder project, this proportion was 3-5%. In continental Europe with severe winters and the navigation period limited to several months, such projects are likely to be systematically uncompetitive.

The main claim to this report is the methodological mistakes made in its development. The document was announced as an analysis of the benefits and costs on the E40 waterway restoration project - this kind of evaluation should be consistent with the neoclassical theory of the public welfare economy. However, the report did not take into account the huge investment costs - about 12 billion euros. From our point of view, this in fact disqualifies the report.

I assume that if the analysis takes into account the costs along the entire E40 route (at the moment they are counted only for two sections of the route), and also include unaccounted multi-billion investment costs and correctly estimated external costs, then it will not be possible to talk about the project profitability.

Both these elements are located on the territory of Poland. The first element is a bypass channel that would connect the Vistula and Mukhavets: the developers considered that it would be inappropriate to use the Medium Bug for the E40, since there are protected areas of the Natura 2000 network. The second element is the valley and bed of the Lower Vistula. It is a rather shallow river, which is preserved in the almost natural state, and corresponds to the second class of navigability while for river-sea vessels a minimum of the fourth class is required. All the other elements of the E40 route on the territory of Belarus and Ukraine were not included in the analysis of benefits and costs. The document sets out the approximate amount of necessary investment, but they are completely unfounded.

They are absolutely different rivers. The Rhine was heavily transformed 150 years ago, when there was no other logistical alternative. Now there is a developed railway network, a network of highways and air routes, the pipeline that has an important place in the transport system of Belarus. And the Danube is a deep-water river, which flows in a serious tectonic fault, this is also an unsuitable example. It must be understood that transport is a means, not an end in itself. If we have a need to transport cargo or passengers from point A to point B, this can be done in different ways. For this, it is not necessary to invest billions in the destruction of the undisturbed nature.
